Amazing game. The game play and mechanics have been greatly improved on from the second. I do prefer the demographic mechanics in the 2nd, as they were more realistic (it showed ethnic populations such as 90% German and 10% Polish BEFORE taking any land, which is accurate to real life) but it still is good. The only negatives are...
1. The absence of a multiplayer (All the AOH games lacked this)
2. A lot of AI art (which can be forgiven as it was made by a single dev) and
3. The tech tree and mission tree as they're very underwhelming

Overall, this game is great and very detailed. You can theorectically go from year ~500 to the future if you want.

Who is this game for?
For fans of Grand Strategy and map-painting who prefer a simplified, accessible scale over the complexity of titles like Crusader Kings or Hearts of Iron. This is for players who don't mind a steep learning curve with little guidance, and those who cherish the sheer joy of global conquest.

THE GOOD (Pros):
Immense Scope & Timeframe: You can jump in from the Age of Civilization right up to a futuristic setting. The sheer volume of scenarios and civilizations is unmatched at this price point.

The New Battle System: The shift to a more RTS (Real-Time Strategy) combat model, rather than simple turn-based movement, adds a much-needed layer of tactical depth to front-line engagements.

Detailed Map and Provinces: With over 13,000 provinces (on the largest map), the level of detail is a massive step up from AoH2, allowing for hyper-granular control over your borders.

Customization Power: The robust editor lets you create any scenario, map, or history you can imagine. This feature guarantees endless replayability, driven entirely by the community.

THE BAD (Cons):
Steep, Unfriendly Learning Curve: The game throws you into the deep end without a proper tutorial. Many vital mechanics are left unexplained, leaving new players frustrated early on.

Missing Diplomacy Features: Several key diplomatic options from AoH2, such as proper trading, ultimatums, and supporting rebellions, are either gone or significantly stripped down, making international relations feel shallow.

Still a Bit Janky: Despite the updates, the game can be prone to bugs, occasional crashes, and clunky UI elements, especially when managing huge empires of 500+ provinces.

"HoI4 for Noobs" Vibe (Too Simple): While accessible, it lacks the deep internal mechanics (like culture, detailed politics, and internal management) that keep Paradox games engaging for thousands of hours.

Final Verdict
Age of History III is a triumphant, yet flawed, continuation of the series. It's an undeniable upgrade in scale and visual quality, providing a massive, engaging sandbox for you to paint the globe your color. It offers the satisfying "map-painting" fix without requiring a three-hour tutorial video.

However, the lack of robust diplomacy and the steep learning barrier stop it from achieving true 'Grand Strategy' greatness. If you are a veteran of the series, buy it‚Äîyou'll love the improvements. If you are new to the genre, be ready for a grind, but you will find a deeply rewarding and time-sinking experience.
This game is simpler than HOI IV, but it still brings an excitement to players.
really good but combat system is only good for medieval, its buns on modern day

After spending 17 hours playing the game I can recommend it to others looking for this type of strategy game.  The learning curve is not too steep, and it is much less complex than Crusader Kings 2 or 3.  I bought it during the Steam Autumn Sale, and it is totally worth the price.  I plan on spending many more hours mastering the game and conquering the world.  I also really like all the different start dates and scenarios.  The replayability factors are endless.
A good simple strategy game, just paint the map and enjoy

Recommended

Don‚Äôt be put off by the rough AI-generated portraits ‚Äî beneath that surface is a deep yet approachable grand strategy experience. The game strikes a nice balance between accessibility and depth, feeling much lighter than something like Crusader Kings II or III but still offering plenty of meaningful decisions.

It doesn‚Äôt hold your hand much at the start, so expect a bit of trial and error early on, but once you learn the systems, it becomes incredibly rewarding. The modding community is also fantastic, constantly adding new scenarios, mechanics, and visual improvements that keep the experience fresh.

Between the multiple start dates, countless possible outcomes, and mod support, this game has excellent replayability. Picked it up on sale and absolutely don‚Äôt regret it ‚Äî it‚Äôs a game you can easily sink dozens of hours into mastering and expanding your empire.

Overall: a solid 8/10 for anyone who enjoys strategy games without getting buried under menus and micromanagement.

negative.review:
The game has potential, but as it is right now I must give a bad review. When you get to mid-end game it becomes unbearable. All you do is click and click. You can only mass-upgrade provinces with middle mouse button, but you need hundreds if not thousands of upgrades by one run. The game has NO province management. If you want to upgrade them so that at least they have 9 runs you need to click manually. If you have 10 provinces I guess it's ok, but when you have hundreds of them, that's where the fun ends. You also don't have proper features for attacking. For example you select multiple armies and you want them to occupy provinces...well that's not going to go. Only one army will do that, so for the rest you need to, again, click and click. I'm really tired of that. 

I wouldn't recommend this game until serious quality of life is being implemented and soon.
Pretty much all of the art, sprites, and backgrounds are all AI slop, please don't buy this.
Editing is extremely counter intutive in addition to a very boring game
Why tf would you change the turns mechanic and just be another wargame??? and yea the game is using AI

30 years in, barely able to push past 5 gold PER MONTH, a single city state decides they dont like me and starts a war unprovoked, comes in with an army size of 30!! a single state able to support an army size of 30 while i cannot even get past 15 without tanking my economy which i built up since the start of the game. needless to say, they destroyed and took over 3 provinces. waste of time .

Just wait for Age of History 2 definitive edition, honestly. Same thing to the second game. Most of the features added here aren't really worth a separate game. Moreover, while novel, the real time mechanic, as well as tech tree, is not very well implemented. The former has some strange occurrences, as it doesn't change to accommodate the times (i.e. the movement of units isn't changed as time advances, meaning the armies late-game take hilariously longer than they should to move places). The latter can be advanced, as is often advanced, by the player and the AI, beyond reason. This wasn't an issue in the earlier game, primarily, if I'm being honest, because tech was an abstracted value in the previous game with little relevance. But here, it's front and center. Getting WW1 infantry in the early 19th century isn't terribly uncommon. While I appreciate the experimentation, the Definitive edition is probably gonna just be the only purchase you make. It will include the good (there are some added diplomatic stuff here, notably the summit feature), and maintain the original quality of the main game, Age of History 2. Hoping some things like the HRE reform system comes to AoH2 DE, as it I think AoH2 is a better base for this type of game.

TL;DR, just wait for Age of History 2: Definitive Edition, it will include the second game, and probably the good of this game.

It's basicaly the second game, but has more useless mechanics, wierder progression, and AI. You still:
- Spam development until a war
- Take out 20 loans to buy a milion troops (that are overleveled because you spammed development)
- Win the war
- Sell every troop
- pay the loans off with money you got from winning the war and selling troops
- repeat
Loop gets boring after about 60 hours. If you want to play age of history just buy the second game. It's the same minus annoying and unnecesary development mechanics and the fucking AI generated "art". If you like AOH3 over AOH2 for it's complexity, just buy Europa universalis or Hoi4.

A huge and interesting upgrade to AOH2, with loads of increased depth, but unfortunately completely ruined, made worthless and unplayable by a single moronic design decision: The game moves forward in ticks (identical to Paradox grand strategies), but there is no auto-pause, no pop-up window, not anything that will sufficiently inform you when you or your allies are attacked. The only clue you get is a small, automatically disappearing text notification hidden in a constant barrage of other, mostly ignorable notifications. The result is that you can't plan what to do, or follow what happens on the map, while time ticks on, because you have to keep your eyes on the notification stream just in case one of them happens to be the war declaration, that will ruin everything if you happen to miss it. It really ruins every damn thing that is good about this game, as stupid as it is, and as much as I would've loved this game otherwise.

Monotonous and AI is easily predictable. Once you have mastered the basic economics engine, its basically a walk in the park. I literally fell asleep playing it, left it on by mistake and now can't get a refund :D
Every fucking siege battle i do i loose even tho my military is way better in numbers and technology. Worst rts game

It's just bad. The early game sucks it's slow and lacks depth. Your early game is largely defined by if your going to ganked or not before you can steamroll the AI. Every nation is basically as strong as the other so there isn't really many challenging starts. 

There is no mid game though. There isn't really a period in which you are at rough parity with the AI. Instead the unpredictable early game practically instantly transitions to a ganking endgame in which no body can begin to challenge you. Seriously you outscale the AI so quickly that they provide no challenge. Speaking of the AI they are extremely passive they spend basically the entire time at peace with occasional wars that make no significant change.

The game is stuck in a rut. It's desired gameplay is boring and unfun. The game is also extremely unflexible so you can't find any other fun alternative playstyles. This won't be fixed as the dev has a habit of abandoning games shortly after launch which he's obviously done because he's gone back to Age of History II.

It's basicaly the second game, but has more useless mechanics, wierder progression, and AI. You still:
- Spam development until a war
- Take out 20 loans to buy a milion troops (that are overleveled because you spammed development)
- Win the war
- Sell every troop
- pay the loans off with money you got from winning the war and selling troops
- repeat
Loop gets boring after about 60 hours. If you want to play age of history just buy the second game. It's the same minus annoying and unnecesary development mechanics and the fucking AI generated "art". If you like AOH3 over AOH2 for it's complexity, just buy Europa universalis or Hoi4.

Not the greatest strategy game in the world, but it is fun and time consuming (mostly a good thing). The only downside is that is really expensive compared to games much higher quality such as EU, Victory, CK, and HOI. Not bad, it is a cool little indie game in a paradox-dominated genre.

30 years in, barely able to push past 5 gold PER MONTH, a single city state decides they dont like me and starts a war unprovoked, comes in with an army size of 30!! a single state able to support an army size of 30 while i cannot even get past 15 without tanking my economy which i built up since the start of the game. needless to say, they destroyed and took over 3 provinces. waste of time .

Just wait for Age of History 2 definitive edition, honestly. Same thing to the second game. Most of the features added here aren't really worth a separate game. Moreover, while novel, the real time mechanic, as well as tech tree, is not very well implemented. The former has some strange occurrences, as it doesn't change to accommodate the times (i.e. the movement of units isn't changed as time advances, meaning the armies late-game take hilariously longer than they should to move places). The latter can be advanced, as is often advanced, by the player and the AI, beyond reason. This wasn't an issue in the earlier game, primarily, if I'm being honest, because tech was an abstracted value in the previous game with little relevance. But here, it's front and center. Getting WW1 infantry in the early 19th century isn't terribly uncommon. While I appreciate the experimentation, the Definitive edition is probably gonna just be the only purchase you make. It will include the good (there are some added diplomatic stuff here, notably the summit feature), and maintain the original quality of the main game, Age of History 2. Hoping some things like the HRE reform system comes to AoH2 DE, as it I think AoH2 is a better base for this type of game.

TL;DR, just wait for Age of History 2: Definitive Edition, it will include the second game, and probably the good of this game.

A huge and interesting upgrade to AOH2, with loads of increased depth, but unfortunately completely ruined, made worthless and unplayable by a single moronic design decision: The game moves forward in ticks (identical to Paradox grand strategies), but there is no auto-pause, no pop-up window, not anything that will sufficiently inform you when you or your allies are attacked. The only clue you get is a small, automatically disappearing text notification hidden in a constant barrage of other, mostly ignorable notifications. The result is that you can't plan what to do, or follow what happens on the map, while time ticks on, because you have to keep your eyes on the notification stream just in case one of them happens to be the war declaration, that will ruin everything if you happen to miss it. It really ruins every damn thing that is good about this game, as stupid as it is, and as much as I would've loved this game otherwise.

Monotonous and AI is easily predictable. Once you have mastered the basic economics engine, its basically a walk in the park. I literally fell asleep playing it, left it on by mistake and now can't get a refund :D
Every fucking siege battle i do i loose even tho my military is way better in numbers and technology. Worst rts game

It's just bad. The early game sucks it's slow and lacks depth. Your early game is largely defined by if your going to ganked or not before you can steamroll the AI. Every nation is basically as strong as the other so there isn't really many challenging starts. 

There is no mid game though. There isn't really a period in which you are at rough parity with the AI. Instead the unpredictable early game practically instantly transitions to a ganking endgame in which no body can begin to challenge you. Seriously you outscale the AI so quickly that they provide no challenge. Speaking of the AI they are extremely passive they spend basically the entire time at peace with occasional wars that make no significant change.

The game is stuck in a rut. It's desired gameplay is boring and unfun. The game is also extremely unflexible so you can't find any other fun alternative playstyles. This won't be fixed as the dev has a habit of abandoning games shortly after launch which he's obviously done because he's gone back to Age of History II.
